Name: Head of Amenhotep the Third Wearing The Double Crown
Description: A head of King Amenhotep the Third, which was found in the Karnak Cachette, belonged to the torso of the same king that is exhibited in the Oriental Museum of Durham University in England. The two pieces were connected for a few months in Cleveland Museum of Art in the U.S.A and in the Louvre Museum in Paris. The statue, as well as the head, is made of steatite glazed with blue faience but the glaze has eroded from the head.The king is depicted in profile, wearing a short curly wig, surmounted by the Double Crown, which is adorned with the uraeus cobra, sign of royalty. Behind him are inscribed his titles such as "The Good God".
